import React from "react"; function CaseJC(props) { return (
Canada 150
  • Client: Jason Clerk
  • Timing: 2021
  • Duration: 6 Months
  • Role: Designer {"&"} Developer
The Backstory

Jason Clerk is a Toronto-based Industrial Designer. His career spans 20+ years, designing products across a variety of categories from household goods, to eyewear, to fitness equipment and more. Historically, Jason has always showcased his portfolio via a PDF that he would personally email out. Jason contacted me to inquire about building a website where clients and potential employers could go to see his work online. Visit Jason{"’"}s website.

Problem to Solve {"&"} Core Considerations

  • - Jason needed a professional website to showcase his body of work and process to clients and potential employers
  • - It was important to Jason to ensure the aesthetic of the site felt authentic to him, being a designer himself. Particularly he wanted a clean, simple, sporty design
  • - The website needed to quickly communicate the breadth and variety of Jason{"’"}s work
  • - Jason did not have professional/high resolution photography of his work

Path to Solution

Each phase of my design process articulated below involved reviewing progress with Jason, collecting feedback, and incorporating the feedback into the design. Additionally, prior to finalizing the design, Jason shared visuals with a few peers (also Industrial Designers) to collect their feedback on the design.

Final Solution - The Ecosystem

In a nutshell, we worked as a team and we leveraged data to inform what we created. I expand further on how we did this in the next section, “Path to Solution”. The final solution was a Canada 150 Ecosystem consisting of 3 main components:
  • - Spotify Brand Campaign (Advertising, PR, Social Media, etc.)
  • - Playlist Hub on Spotify (featured custom co-branded content alongside Spotify Editorial content)
  • - Musical History Timeline Website (co-branded site)

Path to Solution
Outcomes

The project was a first-of-its-kind at Spotify globally, and was strategically significant at a time when Spotify was shifting from growth stage to a streamlined global organization. Several business units moved in lock-step to efficiently meet a varied set of objectives through one comprehensive collaborative effort. The project was shared globally, to 55+ Spotify markets as a best practice for successful collaboration between business units.

Additionally, in a Canada 150 self-evaluation report released by the GoC, media partnerships were considered to have contributed positively to the objectives of engaging youth and supporting diversity and inclusion.

Personal {"&"} Professional Development

The project gave me the opportunity to further develop a few key skills, particularly:

Data-driven mindset - The high stakes for success that accompanied a project of this magnitude reinforced for me the value of having sound data/insights to rely upon in decisioning. As a result, I now try to approach my work with a data-driven mindset to minimize/eliminate guesswork or assumptions.

Cross-functional collaboration - This project truly gave me the freedom to learn how to work collaboratively with other teams at Spotify over several months. In particular, I learned the importance of understanding everyone’s goals (some goals shared by multiple teams and some not) and how to effectively prioritize within the larger group to ensure progress on the project as a whole.

Innovation - This project challenged me to go beyond the standardized solutions we might typically offer up to partners. While those other solutions worked well 95% of the time, and drove efficiencies in our work flow, this project allowed us to flex our innovation skills, leveraging Spotify{"'"}s varied offerings to deliver a completely original partnership.

Specialized Team {"&"} Key Stakeholders

A team of specialists from various business units collaborated to flesh out the holistic project, structuring the components of the partnership and overseeing the complete execution. The team was made up by:
  • Meera Shah - Ad Sales - Spotify
  • Ingrid Rosaeg - Ad Sales - Spotify
  • Liza Haddad - Creative Solutions - Spotify
  • Claudia Seti - Consumer Marketing - Spotify
  • Jacqueline O{"’"}Brien - Consumer Marketing - Spotify
  • Nathan Wiszniak - Label {"&"} Artist Relations - Spotify
  • Gregg Henderson - Editorial - Spotify

Additionally, the folllowing stakeholders contributed extensively to the co-branded aspects of the partnership:

  • Government of Canada (GoC) - Advertising Partner/Client
  • Red Apple Creative - Design and development of the Musical History Timeline Website
  • Cossette Media - GoC Media AOR
  • The Tank Media - GoC Creative AOR

); } export default CaseJC;
